div.head: To no matter who, any body, or no body, wise or foolish Readers.
div.p:
IT was my chance of late to be in Paris upon the top of London-bridge, on the seventy seventh of November, which was Whitsun Eve, when Hiperion was taking a nap in his Meridian about mid-night; I sitting to shade my selfe from the scalding breath of Boreas, under the leaves of a hackney Turnep; there came by me (with tardy haste) a little low man, not above sixteen foot high, I spake not a word to him, but saluted him with humble sublimity; and he very courteously gave mee crosse answers; but at last with negligence and great heed he sate down by mee upon a crimson Sattin Bulrush, and listned close without any attention, while he and I betweene us three demonstratively discourst on that ignoted Knight Sir Leonard Lacke-wit; whose story as I heard it without eares, so Ile expresse it without pen, inke, or paper, wishing the Reader not to bee angry with his judgement, if hee can finde neither Wit nor Sense in it; for I tell him beforehand,
that if he lookes for any such matter, he is deceived; for if it were witty, it would be disproportionable to the Title, and my intention; therefore,
Like it, or leave it, all's one to me,
For I am and will be plaine-dealing
